The Project will assist the Government in implementing a part
of its 15-year plan for small towns water supply and sanitation
development.  The  Project  will  provide  water  supply,  limited
drainage,  and  sanitation  facilities  in  selected  small  towns

and maintenance of the subprojects.

INTRODUCTION

Small urban centers are emerging along the major national highways of Nepal where the

of inadequate safe drinking water supply and poor sanitation conditions on human development
in such centers, the Government initiated a Fifteen-Year Plan for Small Towns Water Supply and
Sanitation  Development  (15-Year  Plan)1  and  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for
assistance in preparing a sector investment project in support of that Plan. In August 1998, ADB

BACKGROUND

A. 

Sector Description

1.

General

Nepal  is  divided  into  three  ecologically  distinct  regions:  mountains,  hills,  and  the  Terai.4
3.
The  regions  are  diverse  in  climate  and  topography  as  well  as  in  socioeconomic  conditions  and
cultural  practices.  Over  the  past  five  decades,  Nepal  has  gradually  been  urbanizing  due  to  the
expansion  of  the  nation’s  road  network,  rural-urban  migration,  and  the  natural  process  of
population growth and development. In less than 44 years, the total population increased from 8
million  to  nearly  22  million,  whereas  the  urban  population  increased  tenfold  –  from  238,000  to
nearly 2.3 million. Although the urban population remains relatively small compared with the rural
population,  urban  growth  rates,  which  increased  the  urban  population  five  times  over  the  last
three decades, are significant. Urbanization has not occurred evenly over the country. Statistics
show  that  most  urbanization  has  occurred  in  the  Terai  and  in  small  towns  along  the  major
national  highways  as  a  result  of  the  rural-urban  migration,  particularly  from  the  hills  to  the
southern  plains  of  the  Terai.  Most  of  the  newly  formed  small  towns  are  either  on  the  east-west
(Mahendra)  highway  or  along  the  north-south  feeder  roads  leading  to  the  east-west  highway.

4.
Nepal  has  abundant  water  resources  —less  than  0.4  percent  of  the  world's  population
possessing about 2.3 percent of the world's water resources. However, drinking water supplies in
most towns are generally inadequate in overall coverage, quantity, and quality. A comprehensive
survey  in  19965  shows  that,  on  average,  only  35  percent  of  the  people  living  in  urban  centers
other than Kathmandu have access to piped water supply. The piped water supplies in the towns
are  usually  intermittent,  with  many  towns  having  water  only  a  few  hours  a  day.  People  without
access  to  these  piped  systems  use  traditional  water  sources  such  as  springs,  ponds,  streams,
and open dug wells. These sources are typically unprotected, and water quality is usually poor.
People spend considerable time and labor collecting water from distant sources (that may or may
not  be  adequate  in  quantity  and  quality).  Few  water  supply  schemes  in  the  towns  have  water
treatment  facilities,  although  basic  sedimentation  and  chlorination  are  sometimes  used.  While
groundwater  usually  requires  little  treatment,  removal  of  excess  iron  and  calcium  carbonate  is
necessary in some areas of the Terai.

5.
The  socioeconomic  survey  in  eight  sample  towns,  conducted  during  the  TA  study  for
preparing  the  Project,  indicates  that  of  those  households  that  have  water  connections,  only  15
percent  have  regular  supplies  and  the  rest  have  only  a  few  hours  of  supply  per  day.  In  fact,
unreliable  supply  is  cited  by  most  households  as  the  main  reason  not  to  have  a  house
connection.  For  households  without  house  connections,  carrying  water  from  other  sources  is  a
daily  chore.  Consequently  these  households  have  very  low  water  consumption  of  less  than  70
liters  per  household  per  day,  roughly  12.5  liters  per  capita  per  day  (lpcd).  Household  members
spend a significant amount of time fetching water: from 0.9 hour (Parsa) to as much as 7.0 hours
per day (Fikkal), or an average of 2.3 hours per day.

6.
For sanitation, the same national survey indicates that about two thirds of the households
in the urban centers have latrines and about 52 percent have access to sanitation systems (open
or  covered  drains  and  soak  pits  for  discharging  liquid  waste).  Using  storm  water  drains  as
sanitary  sewers  is  a  widespread  practice  in  Nepal,  and  is  a  principal  cause  of  pollution  in  the
country’s  watercourses.  Basic  solid  waste  management  systems  in  urban  areas  have  been
functioning for some time and cover about 20 percent of the urban population. However, modern
and  systematic  solid  waste  management  practices  (e.g.,  a  comprehensive  system  of  sanitary
landfills,  regularly  attended  waste  transfer  stations,  and  basic  reuse/recycling  capabilities)  have
yet to be firmly established even in the largest metropolitan areas in Nepal. A Government report6
indicates  that  sanitation-related  diseases  account  for  72  percent  of  the  total  ailments,  and  that
diarrhea  continues  to  be  one  of  the  leading  causes  of  childhood  deaths  (16-25  percent).  The
socioeconomic  survey  conducted  in  the  eight  sample  towns  also  confirms  that  diarrhea  and
dysentery are the most common diseases. Other common illnesses are skin itching, cough, and
malnutrition.  Most  of  the  water  samples  from  hand  pumps  and  dug  wells  in  the  sample  towns
were found to be contaminated.

7.

Lack  of  safe  drinking  supply  and  sanitation  facilities  results  in  worsening  public  health
8.
conditions, deteriorating quality of life, and increased economic costs to the society, such as the
time  spent  on  fetching  water  from  distant  sources,  lost  labor  productivity  due  to  waterborne
diseases,  and  associated  medical  expenditure.  A  study  shows  that  water-related  diseases

9.
Lack of safe and convenient water supply and sanitation facilities, apart from resulting in
high  economic  costs,  also  affects  such  social  development  objectives  as  poverty  reduction,
improving the status of women, and increasing school enrollment of female students. While lack
of  water  supply  and  sanitation  affects  people  of  all  income  levels,  it  is  the  poor  that  are  most
vulnerable.  They  have  little  resources  and  few  alternatives  to  protect  themselves  from  such
adverse  impacts  as  seasonal  drying  out  of  surface  water  sources,  pollution  of  groundwater,  or
spread of waterborne diseases. Women have traditionally been responsible for most household
chores  and  child  care.  Safe  and  convenient  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities  will  lessen
women's  burden  from  these  household  duties  and  allow  them  to  engage  in  revenue-generating
activities, which in turn will increase their voice in the family as well as in the community. Lack of
sanitation  facilities  is  reportedly  one  of  the  major  factors  that  affect  female  students’  school
attendance.  A  school  latrine  provided  under  a  project  supported  by  United  Nations  Children's
Fund  (UNICEF)  in  Chalalganesthan  village  development  committee  (VDC)  has  reportedly
increased female students enrollment by 150 percent (footnote 6).

Urban Categorization and Definition of Small Towns

10.
The  Local  Development  Act  (1991)  and  other  related  regulations  have  classified  urban
settlements into four administrative categories on the basis of existing infrastructure, population,
and potential to generate resources. At the lowest level, is the VDC with a population of less than
20,000. A municipality is the next higher level with a population between 20,000 and 100,000 and
a  minimum  of  NRs2  million  in  annual  revenues.  Larger  urban  centers  with  populations  from
100,000  to  300,000  and  annual  revenues  of  at  least  NRs50  million  are  classified  as  sub-
metropolitan cities. A metropolitan city is at the top of the hierarchy with a minimum population of
300,000 and NRs100 million in annual revenues. 9

11.
The  steady  development  of  the  national  road  network  has  had  a  clear  impact  on  the
commercial  growth  of  several  areas,  especially  in  the  Terai.  In  addition,  such  support
infrastructure as health and education services, banking, and administrative services has further
fueled  rapid  growth  in  certain  areas,  giving  rise  to  new  commercial  centers  with  dramatically

important. Taking into account these considerations, the small towns are defined by the following

cover  capital  and  all  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs;  and  (vi)  participation  of  women,

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

The Project is based on several fundamental considerations. The first relates to meeting
30.
basic human needs and improving the quality of life of small-town residents, especially the low-
income groups. The population in the urban centers along the major national highways has been
increasing rapidly in the past decade mainly as a result of rural migration. The inadequate safe
water supply and sanitation systems in these small towns have adversely affected the quality of
life  and  public  health  conditions  of  the  people  living  in  them.  The  hardship  experienced  by  the
people, especially women, in accessing basic services severely constrains their ability to improve
their  living  conditions.The  socioeconomic  survey  conducted  under  the  project  preparatory  TA
study indicates that in 84 percent of the households, women are responsible for fetching water,
spending  an  average  of  2.3  hours  per  day  on  this  task  during  the  dry  season.  Lack  of  a  safe
drinking  water  supply  and  in-premise  sanitation  facilities,  combined  with  nonhygienic  behavior,
results in poor health profiles and significant economic costs. The low-income groups in the small
towns are particularly vulnerable to the poor conditions of the basic services because of their lack
of resources and alternatives to protect themselves against adverse impacts such as drying out of
surface  water  sources,  pollution  of  groundwater,  and  spread  of  waterborne  diseases.  The
proposed  Project  will  provide  safe  and  convenient  water  supply  to  the  households  and  thereby
allow  the  people,  especially  women,  to  engage  in  productive  activities  to  improve  their  living
conditions.

31.
The second major consideration is the growing role of the small towns in serving as the
economic links between the rural areas and the country's urban economy. The small towns are
the  immediate  markets,  transportation  depots,  and  processing  centers  of  agricultural  products
from  the rural areas. They  are also the immediate labor markets for the seasonal workers from
the  rural  areas  during  the  slack  seasons.  Improved  basic  services  will  therefore  not  only  help
sustain commercial activities that will provide employment to and increase people's income in the
small towns, but also enable farmers to realize gains from income-generating activities. Improved
living  conditions  in  the  small  towns  are  expected  to  help  absorb  the  rural  migrants  and  reduce
pressures  on  the  urban  environment,  infrastructure,  and  employment  in  Kathmandu  valley.  The
majority of the people living in the small towns are migrants from the hills and mountains, drawn
by  the  opportunities  for  business,  employment,  or  education  in  the  urban  centers  where  they
could  better  utilize  their  labor  and  talent.  This  voluntary  resettlement  represents  an  alternative
way for rural people to reduce poverty.

32.
An  additional  consideration  was  to  initiate  a  process  of  empowering  local  communities
and giving them an effective voice in deciding on their development needs. Ensuring that WUSCs

33.
The Project will follow a sector lending modality. This is considered appropriate because
(i) the Government has prepared a 15-year plan for the sector that is satisfactory to ADB, and (ii)

 B. 

Objectives and Scope

12

34.
The  Project  will  improve  water  supply  and  sanitation  conditions  in  40-50  small  towns
(average population about 12,000 per town) where inadequate water supply and sanitation have
adversely affected the health profile and quality of life of the residents. About 0.6 million people,
of  whom  more  than  34  percent  live  below  the  official  poverty  line,  will  benefit  from  the  Project.
The  objectives  are  to  (i)  improve  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities  and  provide  an  HHE
program  in  each  town,  (ii)  support  community  participation  in  the  development  of  water  supply
and sanitation facilities, and (iii) promote community-based water quality monitoring. The Project
has four components:

1.  Public Awareness Campaign and Health and Hygiene Education (Part A)

35.
Public awareness campaigns (PAC) will be carried out through NGOs in all project towns
as soon as a town's participation in the Project is confirmed. The PAC will focus on community
awareness of the project concept including (i) the roles and responsibilities of the WUSCs, local
governments,  TDF,  and  DWSS;  (ii)  the  need  to  share  the  capital  cost  of  the  water  supply
systems;  (iii)  the  linkage  between  the  desired  level  of  services,  the  cost  contribution  and  O&M
expenditure,  and  water  tariffs;  (iv)  the  availability  of  TDF  loans  and  the  need  to  pay  back  the
borrowed  funds;  (v)  women's  representation  in  the  decision-making  process;  and  (vi)  land
acquisition  and  resettlement  issues.  The  PAC  will  lead  to  the  signing  of  the  community  action
plan (CAP) by WUSC representatives signifying their understanding of and agreement in principle
with  the  terms  and  conditions  of  the  Project.  The  project  feasibility  study  for  the  town  will
commence once the CAP is signed.

36.
Health and hygiene education (HHE) will commence in a project town when the detailed
design  for  the  subproject  is  completed  and  accepted  by  the  WUSC,  and  the  town  project
agreement is signed by the WUSC and PMO. The NGO selected to undertake HHE in a project
town  will  coordinate  with  other  institutions  and  civil  groups  –  the  district  health  office,  district
education  office,  UNICEF,  WUSCs,  local  sanitation  clubs,  and  women's  groups  –  in  developing
an  appropriate  training  program.  HHE  will  cover  (i)  school  hygiene  education;  (ii)  community
education;  and  (iii)  focused  training  including  latrine  construction,  solid  waste  management,
animal  waste  management,  and  training  of  community  health  workers.  HHE  is  expected  to
generate  increased  demand  for  improved  household  sanitation  and  the  Project  will  provide
support  (up  to  50  percent  of  construction  cost)  to  low-income  households  interested  in  building
private latrines for purchasing materials unavailable locally. The private in-premise facilities are of
two  basic  types:  pour-flush  latrines  and  ventilated  improved  pit  latrines,  depending  on  the
willingness to pay and preference of the households. Details of HHE are in Appendix 5.

2.  Water Supply and Sanitation Facilities (Part B)

37.

cost  of  O&M,  rainwater  harvesting  will  also  be  considered  as  either  an  alternative  or  a

3. 

Subsidies

71. Water supply and sanitation development in the past was subsidized. While cost recovery
of O&M had been built into the design of the third and fourth ADB-assisted projects, earlier ADB
assistance  to  rural  water  supply  and  sanitation  development  provided  up  to  90  percent  of
subsidies for capital expenditures. This was considered necessary because of the extremely low
level  of  incomes  and  the  perceived  socioeconomic  benefits  of  such  projects  to  the  poor
households. The need to further reduce capital expenditure subsidies is an important part of the
policy  dialogue  between  ADB  and  the  Government.  Under  the  proposed  Project,  local  water
users will contribute up to 50 percent of the capital cost of the subprojects, with 20 percent to be
paid up-front and 30 percent to be paid over the next 12-15 years as subloan repayments. The
proposed cost recovery arrangements are based on the findings of the socioeconomic surveys,
public awareness workshops, sector experience of other external funding agencies in the country,
as well as the policy dialogue.

72.
Nepal  is  ranked  among  the  countries  with  the  poorest  health  profiles  in  the  world.  Poor
sanitation conditions all over the country are major contributors to the poor health profiles. People
in  many  rural  and  semiurban  areas  are  traditionally  reluctant  to  use  latrines,  causing
environmental and health problems in the areas. To encourage people to build and use latrines,
and  considering  the  positive  externalities  of  sanitation  facilities,  the  Project  will  also  provide
subsidies  as  matching  funds  to  low-income  households  that  are  willing  to  construct  private
latrines. The subsidies will be limited to 50 percent of the construction cost of the latrines, and will
be used for procuring materials that are not available locally.

Under the proposed Project, WUSCs will borrow 30 percent of the subproject construction
73.
cost from TDF at an interest rate of 8 percent per annum. TDF obtains these funds from MOF at
an interest rate of 5 percent per annum. These rates are lower than the prevailing market rates,
reflecting a subsidy in the subloans to the WUSCs. Nevertheless, replacing a portion of the grants
with subloans to WUSCs represents unprecedented progress toward cost recovery in the sector.
It is expected that with the increase of income of the people in the small towns, the percentage of
the cost recovery of the capital expenditure could be further improved in a phased manner in the
future.  The  proposed  relending  and  onlending  rates  take  into  consideration  affordability  to  the
low-income  households,  the  financial  constraints  of  the  local  governments,  and  acceptability  to
the general public.

C. 

Social Dimensions

1. 

 Impact on Poverty

According  to  official  statistics,  people  living  below  the  official  poverty  line  in  Nepal,
75.
estimated  at  NRs4,404  per  capita  per  annum  in  1996  prices,  accounted  for  42  percent  in  the
country, 44 percent in the rural areas, 34 percent in the urban areas other than Kathmandu, and 4
percent in Kathmandu. Since most of the small towns are essentially in the rural areas, the ratio
of  the  poor  to  the  total  population  in  the  small  towns  is  estimated  between  34  and  42  percent.
However, poverty has many dimensions. Apart from low income, poverty is also reflected in the
hardships of the poor in accessing basic services and their vulnerability in the absence of such
services. Another dimension of poverty is the poor's lack of power and voice in the development
process. This absence of participation in the development process has resulted in the failure of
many poverty reduction programs to actually reach the poor.

76.
The Project is expected to have positive impacts on poverty. The improved water supply
and  sanitation  facilities  will  significantly  reduce  the  costs  to  the  poor  in  terms  of  purchasing,
treating,  and  storing  water;  the  medical  expenses  on  waterborne  diseases;  and  lost  productive
time  due  to  water  fetching  or  illness.  As  noted  earlier,  the  women  in  the  eight  towns  surveyed
spent  an  average  of  2.3  hours  a  day  fetching  water  during  the  dry  season.  The  Project  will
provide  in-premise  taps  and  community  taps  that  will  reduce  the  hardships  of  the  poor  in
accessing this basic service. The safe water supply combined with sanitation facilities will reduce
the vulnerability of the poor to such adverse changes as drying out of a nearby pond, pollution of
the  shallow  well  water,  or  spread  of  water-borne  diseases.  Apart  from  the  impacts  arising  from
increased  access  to  safe  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities,  the  Project  will  also  create
employment  opportunities  for  low-skilled  labor  in  the  project  towns  for  the  construction  of  the
water supply and sanitation facilities. The Project will maximize the participation of people living in
the small towns in the decision-making process of the town projects, and will provide training and
capacity building to the WUSCs for that purpose. While these measures alone are not sufficient to
eradicate poverty, their combination is expected to have a sustainable positive impact on poverty.

3. 

Governance

78.
The Local Self-Governance Act, 2056 (1999) recently approved by the Government aims
to  strengthen  the  decentralization  process  by  delegating  greater  authority  and  responsibility  to
local authorities. Under the Act, municipalities and VDCs are established as autonomous bodies
that  can  levy  certain  taxes,  enter  into  loan  agreements,  acquire  assets,  and  participate  in  legal
suits. The bodies are also given the rights, roles, and responsibility for protecting water sources,
constructing water supply infrastructure, and preparing, executing and maintaining drinking water
supplies.  The  Act  stipulates  that  village-level  projects  will  be  implemented  through  user
committees  vested  with  the  power  to  collect  fees  from  the  consumers.  The  Act  indicates  that
eventually  the  role  of  line  agencies  will  be  mainly  to  finance  and  facilitate  activities,  under  the
guidance  and  direction  of  the  local  government.  To  support  the  decentralization  process,  the
Project  requires  that  DWSS  transfer  all  the  water  supply  schemes  under  its  operation  to  local
authorities  within  a  10-year  time  frame.  Such  transfer  will  facilitate  the  transformation  of  DWSS
from  a  project  implementer  to  a  development  facilitator,  enhance  local  authorities'  ownership  of
the  installed  facilities,  improve  Government  efficiency  in  infrastructure  development  and  O&M,
and, most importantly, enable local authorities to base future development programs on a realistic
cost of water.

79.
Transparency is an important consideration in project design. ADB and Government have
agreed that, prior to loan effectiveness, DWSS will print and distribute to the local authorities and
WUSCs  the  procedures  of  town  project  formulation,  implementation,  O&M,  and  rights  and
responsibilities  of  each  stakeholder,  including  capital  cost  sharing.  DWSS  will  organize  at  least
five regional workshops with participants from local authorities and WUSCs to explain the design
of the Project and to address the concerns of the local representatives. The communities will be
fully informed and will have the right to decide whether or not to participate in the Project at the
early stages of the project cycle, including PAC, feasibility study, and detailed design. WUSCs will
also participate in bid evaluation and construction supervision. The CAP further requires WUSCs
to fully disclose town project-related information to their members. These measures are expected
to enhance transparency and improve governance at central and local levels.

REVIEW OF ADB RURAL WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION PROJECTS

A.

Review of First Three Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Projects

1.
Up to the early 1990s, ADB had provided three loans to the Government of Nepal for rural
water  supply  and  sanitation  development:  Loan  719-NEP:  Rural  Water  Supply  Project,  for  $9.6
million, approved on 11 December 1984; Loan 949-NEP: Second Water Supply Project, for $14.4
million,  approved  on  31  January  1989;  and  Loan  1165-NEP:  Third  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation
Sector Project, for $20 million, approved on 25 June 1992. ADB’s first two rural water supply and
sanitation  projects  in  the  1980s  were  essentially  supply-driven,  with  the  Government  executing
agency serving as both project implementer and operator of the completed water schemes. There
was  no  community  participation  and  little  cost  recovery.  Reliance  on  the  central  Government
budget  for  the  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  the  rural  water  supply  schemes  was
nonsustainable.  The  main  lesson  learned  from  the  first  and  second  projects  was  that  the
sustainability  of  investments  would  be  at  great  risk  unless  the  communities  (i)  were  proved
mobilized  through  a  comprehensive  education  program;  (ii)  had  established  Water  Users  and
Sanitation  Committees  (WUSCs),  (iii)  had  indicated  a  strong  willingness  to  contribute  to  the
subproject;  and  (iv)  were  involved  in  design,  construction,  and  maintenance.  The  third  project
incorporated these lessons in its basic design. It was formulated using an approach that was driven
by the communities’ needs and demands. This community-oriented approach improved the level of
sustainability  dramatically.  A  second  set  of  lessons  was  related  to  the  importance  of  building

4. 

Key Lessons Learned

9.
The Project was instrumental in the development of an enabling policy and legal framework.
The  National  Water  Supply  Policy  approved  in  1998  stipulates  that  Government  agencies  act  as
facilitators  rather  than  providers  of  water  supply  and  sanitation  services.  The  Drinking  Water
Supply  Regulations,  enacted  as  a  result  of  the  policy  dialogue  pursued  under  the  Project,
established  provisions  for  the  formation,  legal  registration,  and  roles  and  responsibilities  of
WUSCs. The regulations also spelled out the role of WUSCs in water dispute resolution.

10.
The  capability  of  DWSS  and  its  field  offices  in  subproject  preparation  and  design  and  in
managing  and  interacting  with  beneficiary  communities  has  substantially  developed.  DWSS  has
largely  adapted  itself  to  its  new  role  of  facilitator  as  opposed  to  implementer.  Despite  the
impressive gains made in the transition, however, the scale of the challenge indicates the need for
further  reorientation  of  DWSS  toward  social  processes.  ADB  review  missions  discovered  that
DWSS  staff  needed  better  recognition  of  the  importance  of  social  preparation  at  the  community
level. Institutional deficiencies were reflected in some subprojects: community members stated that
DWSS lacks training programs, some WUSCs were not registered, and water user charges have
not yet been fixed by some WUSCs.

A  major  issue  has  been  the  frequent  and  mass  transfer  of  DWSS  field-level  staff.
11.
Discontinuity  in  the  service  of  trained  and  educated  staff  has  had  adverse  implications  for  the
sustainability  of  the  capacities  built  in  DWSS  over  a  long  period.  It  also  affected  the  smooth
implementation of the Project. While this issue is expected to be resolved by the recently amended
Civil  Service  Legislation  that  restricts  the  frequent  transfer  of  project  staff,  the  overall  need  for
further  capacity  building  within  DWSS  and  its  field  offices  needs  to  be  addressed.  ADB  review
missions  recommended  expediting  the  training  activities  and  expanding  the  scope  of  the  training
program  to  adequately  respond  to  the  diverse  training  needs  involved  in  the  management  of  a
community-based  project.  The  project  monitoring  capacity  of  DWSS  was  also  found  to  be  weak
and in need of strengthening.

12.
The  project  efforts  to  enable  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  to  become  effective
Government partners in the water supply and sanitation sector have been partly successful. DWSS
has established the Community and NGO Mobilization Section at the national level, with links to its
field-level offices. This section developed a policy guideline to promote collaboration with the NGO
community, and an action plan for involving NGOs in small gravity-fed systems. However, little real
collaboration  has  taken  place  in  the  field.  The  experience  of  the  Project  suggests  the  need  for
developing more enabling operational procedures within DWSS to build better linkages with NGOs
and clear definitions in future projects of the mechanisms of partnership and the specific roles of
NGOs in the sector.

Introduction

Economic  and  financial  analyses  of  eight  sample  subprojects  were  carried  out  in
1.

Projects, Handbook for the Economic Analysis of Water Supply Projects, and  Guidelines for

alternative  water  supply  development  options,  where  applicable;  calculation  of  the  average
incremental financial cost (AIFC) and average incremental economic cost (AIEC) per cubic meter
of water sold; comparison of AIFC and AIEC with the proposed average tariff to assess subsidies;
calculation  of  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  and  financial  internal  rate  of  return
(FIRR)  for  each  subproject  as  well  as  the  combined  EIRR  and  FIRR  for  all  eight  subprojects;
determination  of  a  possible  tariff  structure  based  on  affordability  and  willingness  to  pay;  and

B. 

Assumptions

2.
The assumptions in the financial and economic analyses are as follows. The capital and
operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  are  based  on  the  least-cost  subprojects  that  meet
design capacity requirements in the planning period of 15 years. A capital allowance equivalent
to 10 percent of the total capital costs is made every 10 years to cover the cost of replacement of
pumping and other equipment, in addition to ordinary O&M expenditures. In the case of gravity
schemes,  an  allowance  of  2  percent  is  provided  every  10  years  for  capital  replacement,  water
meters are assumed to be replaced every 7 years. A residual value equivalent to 50 percent of
project capital costs is assumed in year 20 to take account of the remaining economic life of civil
works and pipelines, which have an assumed economic life of 40 years. The major O&M costs for
each  subproject  are  based  on  water  system  characteristics  and  include  (i)  operation,  (ii)
personnel, (iii) power, and (iv) maintenance.

3.
The  capital  and  operating  cost  streams  in  the  financial  analysis  are  those  used  in  the
economic  analysis  plus  taxes  and  duties  paid  by  WUSC  on  capital  inputs  and  operating  costs.
The  financial  benefit  streams  are  revenues  from  water  sales  to  domestic,  commercial,  and
institutional  customers.  Calculation  of  the  revenues  is  based  on  the  proposed  WUSC  tariffs  in
each  sample  town.  The  tariffs  were  discussed  and  agreed  upon  at  the  stakeholders  meeting  in
November  1999.  The  projected  water  sales  vary  according  to  connection  types:  100  lpcd  for
private indoor connections; 65 lpcd for private yard connections and residential schools; 45 lpcd
for  community  taps;  10  lpcd  for  nonresidential  schools;  500  liters  per  bed  per  day  for  hospitals
and clinics, and 750 liters per day for institutions. Each community tap is assumed to serve five
households. Except for households with private indoor taps, all other residential user groups are
expected to consume within the lifeline block (10 cubic meter [m3] per month). An allowance of 5
percent for bad debts is assumed, implying a collection efficiency of 95 percent.

Cost Recovery, Tariff Structure, and Affordability

22.
Government  guidelines  state  that  tariffs  for  future  programs  for  urban  water  supply
systems  “should  incorporate  adequate  cost  recovery  based  on  differential  consumption  which

 69

Appendix 11, page 7

also provides a lifeline rate for low income households with low consumption and a penalty rate
for excessive consumption.”  In accordance with the guidelines, the project financial objectives for
the  WUSC  systems  are  to  develop  appropriate  water  tariff  structures  to  recover  the  cost  of
production  including  O&M  requirements,  debt  service,  and  a  contribution  toward  future  capital
development, such that they can be financially self-sustaining in the future.

23.
Social  objectives  are  to  ensure  low-income  households  will  have  access  to  affordable
water,  with  water  bills  not  exceeding  5  percent  of  their  household  income.  For  the  poor,  this
requires the tariff structure to include a lifeline block to ensure that the basic needs (estimated at
60 lpcd) can be met at an affordable rate of less than 5 percent of average income (assumed at
NRs250  per  household  per  month).  For  other  domestic  users,  tariff  objectives  are  the  lesser  of
AIFC  and  the  limit  of  affordability.  Average  household  income  in  the  subproject  towns  is
estimated at NRs5,000 per month, with demand of 100 lpcd.  Therefore, indicative tariffs for the
subprojects  in  the  financial  analysis  are  based  on  cost  recovery  objectives  to  increase  the
charges for water toward the economic costs to improve the efficiency of resource allocation and
demand management; to ensure revenues will be adequate to meet cash flow requirements for
operations, debt service, and capital replacement; and to provide services at an affordable rate,
recognizing the needs of lower income users.

24.
For  each  subproject,  indicative  tariffs  were  developed,  based  on  an  assessment  of
affordability  that  would  be  adequate  to  cover  all  operating  costs,  debt  servicing,  and  capital
replacement, while maintaining a positive cash flow. The projections show that, as long as tariffs
are regularly increased to cover inflation (maintained in real terms), the WUSCs should be able to
generate cash surpluses for expansion or major capital replacement. A blocked tariff is adopted in
the  financial analysis  of the subproject towns, with a lifeline block of 10 m3  per  month  at  a  rate
affordable  to  low-income  users.  A  second  block  of  tariff  is  set  at  1.5  times  the  lifeline  rate  for
consumption beyond lifeline amount, or at least AIFC per m3. Table A11.6 summarizes the tariff
structure  and  impacts  for  each  project  in  terms  of  estimated  monthly  household  cost  and
affordability,  as  measured  by  percentage  of  household  income  for  average  and  low-income
households.  The  rates  range  from  a  low  of  1.7  percent  income  for  low-income  consumers  in
Birendranagar, to the higher limit of 5 percent for average users in Fikkal and Attariya. Based on
the  affordability  criterion  of  charges  not  exceeding  5  percent  of  income,  the  required  tariffs  are
within both poor and average households’ ability to pay.
